toolCalls.description:
This tool executes a given shell command as `powershell.exe -NoProfile -Command <command>`. Command can start background processes using PowerShell constructs such as `Start-Process -NoNewWindow` or `Start-Job`.

      The following information is returned:

      Command: Executed command.
      Directory: Directory where command was executed, or `(root)`.
      Stdout: Output on stdout stream. Can be `(empty)` or partial on error and for any unwaited background processes.
      Stderr: Output on stderr stream. Can be `(empty)` or partial on error and for any unwaited background processes.
      Error: Error or `(none)` if no error was reported for the subprocess.
      Exit Code: Exit code or `(none)` if terminated by signal.
      Signal: Signal number or `(none)` if no signal was received.
      Background PIDs: List of background processes started or `(none)`.
      Process Group PGID: Process group started or `(none)`

messages.content: I can't download Throttlestop due to anti-bot measures. I'll search for a Chocolatey package instead.

thoughts.subject: Attempting Downloads' Obstacles
thoughts.description: I'm hitting a snag. Both download attempts, from different sites, are blocked. It seems I need JavaScript enabled to bypass Cloudflare's bot protection, something `Invoke-WebRequest` can't manage on its own.

thoughts.subject: Searching Alternative Installation Methods
thoughts.description: I'm now switching gears. Downloading directly seems impossible, stymied by those pesky bot protections. So, I'm pivoting to alternative installation avenues. My current line of thought is to search for a Chocolatey package for ThrottleStop. Perhaps that will bypass the download issues altogether.

messages.content: Okay, I've found a Chocolatey package for Throttlestop. I'll install it now with `choco install throttlestop -y`.

thoughts.subject: Confirming the Installation
thoughts.description: I'm proceeding with the installation of ThrottleStop. Chocolatey has a package ready, which simplifies the process. I'm using `choco install throttlestop -y` to install it; the `-y` flag is a handy shortcut to bypass any confirmation prompts. This should be quick!

toolCalls.description:
This tool executes a given shell command as `powershell.exe -NoProfile -Command <command>`. Command can start background processes using PowerShell constructs such as `Start-Process -NoNewWindow` or `Start-Job`.

      The following information is returned:

      Command: Executed command.
      Directory: Directory where command was executed, or `(root)`.
      Stdout: Output on stdout stream. Can be `(empty)` or partial on error and for any unwaited background processes.
      Stderr: Output on stderr stream. Can be `(empty)` or partial on error and for any unwaited background processes.
      Error: Error or `(none)` if no error was reported for the subprocess.
      Exit Code: Exit code or `(none)` if terminated by signal.
      Signal: Signal number or `(none)` if no signal was received.
      Background PIDs: List of background processes started or `(none)`.
      Process Group PGID: Process group started or `(none)`

messages.content: Choco install failed due to lack of admin rights, and I can't escalate. Instead, I'll retry manual installation. I suspect anti-bot measures blocked my previous download attempt, so I'll try again from TechSpot using a common browser user-agent with `Invoke-WebRequest`. First, I'll download it as an HTML file to check for another challenge page.

thoughts.subject: Addressing Installation Failure
thoughts.description: I've determined the initial installation attempt failed. It seems I didn't have the required administrative privileges. The `choco install` command wouldn't execute correctly. The error message provides actionable next steps. I need to run this from an elevated shell to get it going.

thoughts.subject: Attempting Manual Download
thoughts.description: I'm switching to a manual installation approach. The `choco install` command failed due to missing administrative privileges. I've re-attempted the download from TechSpot, incorporating a browser-like user agent to bypass potential anti-bot measures. I'm now testing the download request with `Invoke-WebRequest`.

thoughts.subject: Evaluating Download Strategy
thoughts.description: I'm now focusing on the manual download, as `choco` install failed due to permission restrictions.  I've attempted a download with `Invoke-WebRequest` using a browser user agent to bypass any anti-bot defenses.  The resulting HTML file is now being inspected to confirm a successful retrieval and assess the server's response.

messages.content: I can't install Throttlestop. Direct download is blocked, and Choco fails without admin rights. I've run out of options. I'll ask the user to download the file and place it in a specified directory so I can proceed.

thoughts.subject: Evaluating Download Obstacles
thoughts.description: I'm hitting a wall with this download. Even spoofing the user agent didn't work against the Cloudflare challenge on TechSpot. It's looking like `Invoke-WebRequest` isn't going to cut it for this one. I've tried all the usual tricks. Now what?

thoughts.subject: Addressing Installation Hurdles
thoughts.description: I'm now contemplating asking for user assistance. Direct downloads are blocked, and even alternative approaches like `choco install` are failing. I'm leaning toward requesting the user manually download the file. It's the most pragmatic solution given my limitations. I can handle the install once the file is available locally, but I can't overcome the current download obstacles.

toolCalls.name: run_shell_command

args.command:
Write-Output "I am unable to download the ThrottleStop installer automatically due to website protections. Please download it for me."
Write-Output "1. Open a web browser and go to: https://www.techspot.com/downloads/5863-throttlestop.html"
Write-Output "2. Click the 'Download Now' button and save the file."
Write-Output "3. Please tell me the full path to the downloaded file (e.g., C:\Users\YourUser\Downloads\ThrottleStop.zip)."

I am unable to download the ThrottleStop installer automatically due to website protections. Please download it for me.
1. Open a web browser and go to: https://www.techspot.com/downloads/5863-throttlestop.html
2. Click the 'Download Now' button and save the file.
3. Please tell me the full path to the downloaded file (e.g., C:\Users\YourUser\Downloads\ThrottleStop.zip).
